replies.body:
Hey! 

Wanted to pop in here and explain what's going on with Yorick! 

You're right that he hasn't received a skin since launch and his skin catalog only has two skins. We aren't ignoring Yorick, although from the looks of the amount of skins he has, it may appear that way.

For a bit of context here, Yorick needs a rework/update before the Skins team takes him under our wing and gives him more skins. 

*But why can't you make a skin and give him the rework after?* That's the most common question I see when I explain the rework/update situation, and it's a totally valid question. 

When a champion is updated (let's use Sion as an example for this), there are a ton of changes made, both in model, as well as the kit. If we were to create a skin for him now, the Champion Update team would need to rip apart the work we did to make it work for the update they create. This could mean making a new set of particles, a new model, etc. It's basically like doing the work twice. So, rather than doing that, the Skins team creates other skins for other champions while we await the go-ahead to work on a new skin. This rule also applied to Poppy (she's eligible for a skin now)! and currently Taric. 

The other big reason for doing this is because we don't want players to become attached to a skin and then have it completely re-imagined. So, let's say we put out a Crazy Cat Lady Yorick skin (Rito pls), but with the rework, he didn't have a spell that used your favorite cat model. That may ruin how cool the skin is to you, which is a pretty crappy situation. So, rather than taking away things you love, we hold off on creating them until we've got a solid, shiny, new base to work from, which means the skins you purchase won't be changing any time in the near future.
What if you just did a chroma pack for Yorick?
Unfortunately not - similar rules apply. It'd be twice the work in terms of creating the chroma packs.
Chroma packs have seemed to die off as of late. Is that due to bandwidth or lack of consumer interest in the idea?

Can you explain why this whole "oh it would be twice the work" excuse is allowed to be used for as long as Yorick is slated for a rework?

Because, y'know, he's been slated for one for THREE YEARS.

At what point does this reasoning stop holding water for the skins team? Because I gotta say, after two years of the same excuse, one would think you guys would just take the double load of work rather than ignore a portion of your playerbase the way you're doing.

Or at least light a fire under someone so they actually get off their ass and make the damn rework.

Yorick is a complicated champion, similar to Zyra in terms of models. He not only has himself, but several additional models utilized in his kit. The Champion Update team has quite a lot on their plate, both with announced projects, as well as stuff coming further down the line. The last thing skins wants to do is pile more work on their plate with a skin that's going to need to be completely updated visually, and even more so if the kit should change drastically. 

As mentioned earlier, 

*The other big reason for doing this is because we don't want players to become attached to a skin and then have it completely re-imagined. So, let's say we put out a Crazy Cat Lady Yorick skin (Rito pls), but with the rework, he didn't have a spell that used your favorite cat model. That may ruin how cool the skin is to you, which is a pretty crappy situation. So, rather than taking away things you love, we hold off on creating them until we've got a solid, shiny, new base to work from, which means the skins you purchase won't be changing any time in the near future.*

Right, and I understand all that, but where's the point when you stop waiting for something that doesn't appear to be coming? At this point, any additional work the ChampUp team does, they put on their OWN plate, by slating Yorick for a rework and then repeatedly working on other champions while shelving him for literally years. There comes a point where either they need to full stop and _get Yorick done,_ or accept that he's not moving forward and that they will have additional work to do on him when they finally _do_ start moving again.

I dunno, the whole situation just rubs me the wrong way. I've never in my life had a job where "it'll be easier if I don't do this now and wait for someone else to do their job first" has worked as a reason, unless I could prove that the someone else in question was doing their part of the job already or very soon. Plus, the whole three years of waiting thing isn't fun at all for someone who likes Yorick's lore/identity/whatever :/
You were saying the same thing about Fiora, but she looks almost the same as before. Will Yorick really look THAT different from what he is now so we have to wait so long?

I don't have a lot of context on what any kind of plan is for him - I only tackle the skins portion of this. The example I'm using here is a worst-case, and one of the larger reasons we hold off on a skin - we don't initially know what the scope is for an update. 

Once we know, i.e. in Fiora's case, we can build a skin in a similar time frame and have the update come out, followed by a skin in the next patch.
I know its been thrown around before but what if a new skin was released with a {{champion:83}} rework? Would something like that be possible?
It's not impossible - we did something similar with Fiora's update by releasing PROJECT: Fiora shortly after.

There are a number of problems, historical and current, in the creation of a new Yorick skin:

1.  **Yorick is not Riot's favorite champion:**  Yorick was released at a time when the company was adding a new champion every patch, and the team felt pressured to release Yorick, a champion they weren't _fully_ behind from the start.  (For example, Yorick's zombie ult was created a week before release and was originally a combination of Thresh's ult and Karthus's E).

2.  **Yorick is difficult to create skins for:**  Yorick falls under the same "category" as Elise, Zyra and Zac in that there is much more to the champion than the main model itself.  The ghouls would each require a new look to differentiate them between each skin, along with the effects.  Not that this should have stopped them from doing anything, but...

3.  **Yorick was put on a "no promotion" list by Riot:**  Yorick was removed from the free week rotation nearly three years ago (along with Poppy) and was put on a "no new skins" list soon afterwards.  You'll also notice that Yorick's obscured on his Pentakill skin page in the client (He's hidden by his skins on the left side) and was barely mentioned during the 2014 Pentakill event.  This lack of promotion also included new skins, which could have been done long before he was put on the rework list.  _Speaking of which..._

4.  **Yorick is _scheduled_ for a rework... maybe:**  Simply put, Yorick's rework has been shifted to the back burner in favor of easier projects, like Sion and Poppy.  Taric is supposedly next on the list, with his art assets needing to be cemented at the present time.  However, just after Yorick on the "high priority" list is Urgot and _there's no guarantee_ that Riot or ChampUp would finish working on the Gravedigger before starting on the Headman's Pride.

5.  **Delivering a skin for Yorick now would only lead to more work for ChampUp:**  Another champion in the same boat as Yorick was Trundle.  The skins team was asked to not make new projects for Trundle until his rework was done in 2013, which leads to...

6.  **There's no _guarantee_ that Yorick would remain Yorick after the rework:**  See Trundle after the Freljord patch.  Riot could pull something even bigger than that fiasco and change the green undead brute into a generic necromancer, thus destroying any skins that could have been made.

So, while the skins team is waiting _right now_ for the rework to get done before Yorick is eligible for a new skin (which might come in late 2017 If Sion is any indication), they're also at fault for having _never_ done one beyond his two launch skins.
